children.text: Okay, I need to translate this Java code to C. Let's look at the Java code first.

children.text: The Java code starts by importing Scanner, but in C we don't have that. So I'll need to use scanf for input. Then there's a public class atcoder_ABC108_B. In C, there's no classes, so I'll have to convert the methods into functions.

children.text: The revpos function in Java takes two int arrays p and q, does some calculations, and returns a new int array. In C, since we can't return an array directly, I'll need to pass the result array as a parameter.

children.text:
Also, arrays in C are passed by pointer, so modifying them in the function will affect the original. Looking at the revpos function steps:
1. Calculate vec as p[i] - q[i] for each element. Since the arrays are of length 2, vec is a 2-element array.

children.text:
2. Swap vec[0] and vec[1], but then set vec[1] to -vec[0] (from the original code: after swapping, vec[0] becomes the old vec[1], vec[1] becomes -old vec[0]). Wait, let's see the Java code:

vec is initialized as p[i] - q[i]. So for i=0 and 1, vec[0] is p[0]-q[0], vec[1] is p[1]-q[1]. Then tmp = vec[0], vec[0] = vec[1], vec[1] = -tmp. So the new vec is [vec[1], -vec[0]]. Then newpos is q[i] + vec[i]. So the new position is q plus this rotated vector. So the revpos function returns a new position based on rotating the vector from p to q by 90 degrees counter-clockwise?

So in C, for each position after the first two, we need to call revpos with the previous two positions and store the result. So for position[2], we can pass position[0], position[1], and store into position[2]. Similarly, position[3] is revpos(position[1], position[2]). Then there's a check: if position[0] == revpos(position[2], position[3]), then print "OK". But in Java, comparing arrays with == compares references, which is incorrect. Wait, the original Java code has a bug here. Because in Java, comparing two arrays with == checks if they are the same object, not if their contents are equal. So that check will always be false, unless revpos returns the same array instance, which it doesn't. So that part of the code is probably a mistake. However, in C, since we can't compare arrays, we'll have to compute the revpos of position[2] and position[3], then compare each element to position[0]. But let's see the steps:

But the way revpos works: revpos(a, b) computes a point that's the result of rotating the vector from a to b 90 degrees CCW, then adding that to b.

children.text: After swapping, vec becomes (vy, vx). Then vec[1] becomes -tmp (which was the original vec[0]). So the new vec is (vy, -vx). That's a rotation of 90 degrees clockwise.

children.text: Because rotating a vector (x, y) 90 degrees clockwise gives (y, -x). So yes. So the function revpos(p, q) returns the point q plus the vector (p - q) rotated 90 degrees clockwise.
